intro: Calamus leloi, commonly known as the golden calamus, is a species of flowering plant in the family Araceae. It is native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia, including parts of Indonesia and the Philippines. The plant is characterized by its long, slender rhizomes and broad, arrow-shaped leaves that can grow up to several meters in length. It produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in a spadix, typical of the Araceae family. Calamus leloi is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is also used in traditional medicine in some cultures.
